expanded_description: Not all inequalities have a solution set that is a simple interval or union of intervals. Some inequalities are true for all real numbers, while others have no solution at all. Recognizing these special cases is crucial for complete understanding and prevents students from incorrectly stating solutions that don't exist or missing solutions that are always true.

core_concept.principle: When solving an inequality, if the variable cancels out completely, examine the resulting statement: if it's true (like $0 < 5$ or $2 \geq -3$), the inequality is an identity and the solution is all real numbers. If it's false (like $0 > 5$ or $-2 \geq 1$), the inequality has no solution. These are called special cases.
core_concept.explanation: Think of these special cases as extreme outcomes in a negotiation. Sometimes, no matter what value you propose, the condition is always met—like a store policy that 'all items are under $\$100$' which is always true if nothing costs that much. Other times, the condition is impossible—like 'you must be both under 10 and over 20 years old,' which no one can satisfy.

image.alt: Number lines showing all real numbers (entire line shaded) and no solution (nothing shaded)
image.caption: Figure 6.8.1: Special cases - all real numbers vs no solution.

sections.introduction: Before exploring inequalities, let's review the special cases we encountered with equations: identities and contradictions.

key_concept.definition:
In equations, when the variable cancels:
• If the resulting statement is true (like $3 = 3$), the equation is an identity and has infinitely many solutions (all real numbers).
• If the resulting statement is false (like $3 = 5$), the equation is a contradiction and has no solution.
key_concept.context: Inequalities have similar special cases, but the rules are slightly different because inequality signs can sometimes be true for all numbers even when equations wouldn't be.

image.alt: Examples of identity and contradiction in equations
image.caption: Figure 6.8.3: Equation special cases.

worked_examples.title: Equation Special Cases Review
worked_examples.problem:
Classify each equation as identity, contradiction, or conditional:
a) $2x + 5 = 2x + 5$
b) $3x - 2 = 3x + 4$
c) $4x + 1 = 2x + 7$
worked_examples.final_answer: a) Identity, b) Contradiction, c) Conditional
worked_examples.concept_applied: When variable cancels, check the remaining statement.

sections.section_title: 6.8.2 Inequalities with All Real Numbers as Solution
sections.introduction: Sometimes an inequality simplifies to a statement that is always true, regardless of the variable's value. In such cases, the solution is all real numbers.

introduction_image.alt: Number line with entire line shaded
introduction_image.caption: Figure 6.8.6: All real numbers solution.

key_concept.definition: When solving an inequality, if the variable cancels and the resulting statement is true (e.g., $3 > -2$, $0 \leq 5$, $-4 < 1$), then the inequality is true for all real numbers. This means any value of the variable satisfies the original inequality.
key_concept.context: This happens when the inequality is an identity—it's always true, like saying 'a number plus one is greater than the number minus one,' which is true for every number.

image.alt: Examples leading to all real numbers
image.caption: Figure 6.8.7: Inequalities that are always true.

worked_examples.title: Identifying All Real Numbers Solutions
worked_examples.final_answer: a) All real numbers, b) All real numbers, c) All real numbers, d) All real numbers
worked_examples.concept_applied: When the variable cancels and the remaining statement is true, the solution is all real numbers.

image.alt: Summary of all real numbers solutions
image.caption: Figure 6.8.9: All real numbers summary.

sections.introduction: Other inequalities simplify to statements that are never true. In these cases, no value of the variable satisfies the inequality—there is no solution.

key_concept.definition: When solving an inequality, if the variable cancels and the resulting statement is false (e.g., $3 < -2$, $0 \geq 5$, $-4 > 1$), then the inequality has no solution. This means no value of the variable can make the original inequality true.
key_concept.context: This happens when the inequality is a contradiction—it's impossible, like saying 'a number is both greater than 5 and less than 3,' which can never happen.

image.caption: Figure 6.8.11: Inequalities that are never true.

worked_examples.title: Identifying No Solution Cases
worked_examples.final_answer: a) No solution, b) No solution, c) No solution, d) No solution
worked_examples.concept_applied: When the variable cancels and the remaining statement is false, there is no solution.

sections.introduction: Let's compare the conditions that lead to all real numbers versus no solution, and see how they differ from equations.

key_concept.definition:
After the variable cancels:
• If the remaining inequality is TRUE (e.g., $3 > -2$, $0 \leq 5$, $-4 < 1$), the solution is ALL REAL NUMBERS.
• If the remaining inequality is FALSE (e.g., $3 < -2$, $0 \geq 5$, $-4 > 1$), there is NO SOLUTION.
key_concept.context: Note: The truth of the statement depends on the numbers and the inequality sign. $-3 < 1$ is true, while $-3 > 1$ is false.

image.alt: Table of true and false statements
image.caption: Figure 6.8.15: True vs false statements.

worked_examples.title: Determining Special Cases
worked_examples.problem:
After solving, the variable canceled. For each resulting statement, determine whether the inequality has all real numbers or no solution:
a) $5 > 2$
b) $-3 \leq -7$
c) $0 \geq -4$
d) $8 < 3$
e) $-2 > -5$
f) $4 \leq 4$

step_by_step.explanation: -3 is NOT less than or equal to -7, false
0 is greater than or equal to -4, true
4 is less than or equal to 4, true

worked_examples.final_answer: a) All real, b) No solution, c) All real, d) No solution, e) All real, f) All real
worked_examples.concept_applied: Evaluate the truth of the remaining statement to determine the solution type.

sections.introduction: Compound inequalities can also lead to all real numbers or no solution, sometimes in interesting ways.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 6.8.18: Special cases in compound inequalities.

key_concept.definition:
For AND inequalities, if the conditions have no overlap, there is no solution. If one condition contains the other, the more restrictive one determines the solution.
For OR inequalities, if the conditions overlap and cover the entire number line, the solution is all real numbers. If one condition contains the other, the less restrictive one determines the solution.
key_concept.context: These results are consistent with the union and intersection concepts behind AND and OR.

image.alt: AND with no overlap (no solution), OR with complete overlap (all real numbers)
image.caption: Figure 6.8.19: Compound inequality special cases.

worked_examples.title: Compound Inequality Special Cases
worked_examples.problem:
Solve each compound inequality:
a) $x > 5$ and $x < 3$
b) $x < 2$ or $x > 7$
c) $x \geq 0$ and $x \leq -2$
d) $x \leq 4$ or $x \geq 1$
e) $x > 3$ and $x > 1$
f) $x < 5$ or $x < 2$

step_by_step.explanation: No number can be both >5 and <3
These overlap and cover all numbers

worked_examples.final_answer: a) No solution, b) $x < 2$ or $x > 7$, c) No solution, d) All real numbers, e) $x > 3$, f) $x < 5$
worked_examples.concept_applied: AND requires both; OR requires at least one. Overlaps can lead to special cases.

image.alt: Summary of special cases in compound inequalities
image.caption: Figure 6.8.21: Compound inequality special cases summary.

sections.introduction: Real-world situations can also lead to inequalities that are always true or never true.

introduction_image.alt: Real-world scenarios with always true or impossible conditions
introduction_image.caption: Figure 6.8.22: Real-world special cases.

key_concept.definition: Some real-world constraints are impossible (e.g., 'you must be at least 5 feet tall and under 4 feet tall') leading to no solution. Others are automatically satisfied (e.g., 'your age is greater than 0' is always true for any person) leading to all real numbers within the domain.
key_concept.context: Recognizing impossible situations can save time and prevent trying to find solutions that don't exist.

image.alt: Examples: impossible height requirement, always-true age condition
image.caption: Figure 6.8.23: Real-world examples.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Impossible Conditions
worked_examples.problem:
Determine whether each situation has a possible solution, is always true, or is impossible:
a) A ride requires riders to be at least 48 inches tall and no more than 48 inches tall.
b) All humans are less than 10 feet tall.
c) You need to be at least 16 years old and under 15 years old to enter.
d) The temperature is greater than -460°F (absolute zero) for any real temperature.

step_by_step.step: a) At least 48 and no more than 48
b) Humans are less than 10 feet tall
step_by_step.explanation: This is true for all humans (within domain)
No number can be both ≥16 and <15
Absolute zero is -460°F, all real temperatures are above this

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Possible (exactly 48), b) Always true, c) Impossible, d) Always true
worked_examples.concept_applied: Real-world constraints can lead to all real numbers (within domain) or no solution.

sections.section_title: 6.8.7 Common Errors and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Students often make specific mistakes when dealing with special cases. Awareness helps prevent these errors.

classifications.value: Trying to write a specific number when the variable cancels.

image.alt: Correct 'all real numbers' vs incorrect specific inequality
image.caption: Figure 6.8.26: Error - stating a specific solution when variable cancels.

examples.explanation: Correct: The variable is gone; $3 > 1$ is true, so all real numbers

classifications.value: Misjudging whether the final statement is true or false.

examples.explanation: Correct: $-3$ is greater than $-5$, so true

classifications.value: Forgetting that real-world domains may restrict 'all real numbers'.
characteristics: Stating all real numbers when only positive numbers make sense

image.alt: All real numbers vs positive numbers only
image.caption: Figure 6.8.28: Error - ignoring domain restrictions.

examples.process: Error: For age $a$, $a + 1 > a$ is true for all real numbers, but age can't be negative
examples.explanation: Correct: All real numbers in the domain (a ≥ 0) but mathematically all reals

worked_examples.title: Correcting Special Case Errors
worked_examples.problem: A student solved $3x - 5 > 3x + 2$ and wrote $x > 7$. Identify and correct the error.

step_by_step.explanation: Since the statement is false, there is no solution
Student incorrectly subtracted and got $x > 7$, not realizing the variable canceled

worked_examples.concept_applied: When variable cancels, don't keep solving—evaluate the remaining statement.

image.alt: Summary table of common special case errors and corrections
image.caption: Figure 6.8.30: Common errors summary.

sections.introduction: Apply your skills to identify and solve inequalities with special cases.

worked_examples.title: Mixed Practice Set
worked_examples.problem:
Solve each inequality. State whether the solution is all real numbers, no solution, or a specific inequality.
1) $4x + 7 > 4x + 3$
2) $2x - 5 \leq 2x - 8$
3) $3(x + 2) < 3x + 5$
4) $5x + 2 \geq 5x + 2$
5) $2x - 4 > 2x + 1$
6) $7 - 3x \leq 7 - 3x$
7) Real-world: A store advertises 'prices are lower than any other store' and 'prices are higher than any other store.' Is this possible? Write an inequality and determine if it has a solution.

step_by_step.explanation: Let $p$ be store's price, $c$ be competitor's price. 'Lower than any other' means $p < c$ for all $c$. 'Higher than any other' means $p > c$ for all $c$. These cannot both be true.

worked_examples.final_answer:
1) All real numbers
2) No solution
3) No solution
4) All real numbers
5) No solution
6) All real numbers
7) No solution (impossible)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Practice identifying when variable cancels and evaluating the resulting statement.

summary: When solving inequalities, sometimes the variable cancels out completely. In these cases, we examine the resulting numerical statement. If the statement is true (e.g., $3 > -2$, $0 \leq 5$, $-4 < 1$), then the inequality is an identity and the solution is all real numbers. If the statement is false (e.g., $3 < -2$, $0 \geq 5$, $-4 > 1$), then the inequality is a contradiction and has no solution. These special cases also appear in compound inequalities: AND inequalities may have no solution if the conditions don't overlap, while OR inequalities may give all real numbers if the conditions together cover all values. In real-world contexts, always consider the domain—'all real numbers' mathematically may be restricted by practical considerations (e.g., age cannot be negative). Recognizing these special cases prevents errors and deepens understanding of the nature of inequalities.
